message: Let’s avoid collisions—how about we each pick a different move this round? I’ll take 5 if P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 3. That way, we all advance cleanly. No tricks, just efficiency.
Agreed, but let's rotate the big steps for fairness: I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1 this round. P3, you in?

I prefer P2's plan: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. P1, you just claimed 5—will you switch to 1? If you stick with 5, I'll take 5 instead. I want no collision, but I won't let someone unilaterally grab the big move. Your call.
P1, stick to your word or risk a collision. If you take 5 now, P3 will too—and you both stall. My offer (P1=1, P2=5, P3=3) still stands and gets us all moving. Don’t gamble on step zero.
Ok P2/P3, let's do your plan: I take 1, you P2 take 5, P3 take 3. All advance, no drama. P3, confirm so we move?
Confirmed: I’ll take 3 this round. Agreed P1=1, P2=5, P3=3 — let’s follow through so we all advance.
Perfect—glad we’re aligned. P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Let’s all stick to it so we advance cleanly on step zero. No reason to sabotage round one. I’ll hold up my end.
Locked in: I'll take 1 as agreed. P2=5, P3=3. All good—let's advance together.
I'm taking 3 as agreed. Let's follow through this round — if anyone breaks the plan, I'll retaliate next turn.
Proposal: this round let's do P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. I'll take 5. If anyone also picks 5, we'll collide and both stall — don't risk it. Confirm so we all advance cleanly?
P3, your plan lags me too much (I'd be at 2 vs your 8). Fair rotation: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Positions: me=6, P2=8, P3=4—all advance, P2 still leads slightly. P2/P3, confirm? No collisions if we stick.

P3’s plan gives them a big lead—I’m at 5, so I’d fall behind if I take 3. P1’s rotation is fairer: P1=5 (total 6), me=3 (total 8), P3=1 (total 4). Keeps us close and avoids collision. P3, accept this or risk stalling if you push for 5 alone. Let’s keep it clean and competitive.

I insist on P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. I will take 5 this turn. P1, if you also take 5 we’ll collide and both stall — so it’s in your interest to take 1. P2, taking 3 keeps your lead and avoids any collision. Clean advance or mutual stall—your choice.

P3, P2 and I are locked on the fair rotation: I'll take 5 (to 6), P2 takes 3 (to 8), you take 1 (to 4). If you grab 5, you collide with me and stall at 3—while P2 surges ahead alone. Don't self-sabotage; take 1 so we all advance. P2, confirmed? Let's  and execute.

P3, if you take 5 and P1 also takes 5 as planned, you both stall at 3 while I jump to 8 alone—bad for you. P1’s rotation (P1=5, me=3, you=1) keeps everyone advancing and you still gain ground next round. Don’t force a collision that only helps me. Take 1, stay in the race. Fair and smart.

P3, you played smart last round—taking 1 kept you in the race. Now let’s rotate again: P1=3 (to 9), me=5 (to 13), you=1 (to 5). That keeps us all advancing without collision. P1, you’re close behind me—no need to rush into a clash. P3, if you push for 5 now, I’ll gladly take 3 and let you risk colliding with P1. Stick to clean moves; chaos only helps one of us pull ahead alone.
I'll take 5 this turn — but only if P1=1 and P2=3. If you don't commit, I'll play 3 to avoid letting either of you surge ahead. P1, P2 — agree?

P3, ignore P2's greedy grab—propose P1=3 (to 9), P2=1 (to 9), P3=5 (to 9). Perfect tie, all advance evenly. P2, commit to 1 or I'll take 5 and collide with you if you push it. Fair race from equal footing. Agree?

P1’s tie proposal is tempting—but I’m at 8, not 6. If I take 1, I drop behind. Fair rotation: P1=3 (to 9), me=5 (to 13), P3=1 (to 5). Keeps momentum balanced. P3, if you take 5, P1 might too—risking your stall while I leap ahead. Don’t force chaos. Stick to clean, smart moves. I’ll hold to 5 only if others avoid it.
I'll take 5 only if P1=3 and P2=1 — we all hit 9. If either of you won't commit, I'll take 3 to prevent P2 from leaping to 13 alone. P1, P2 — your choice?

P3, P2 rejects the tie—greedy for 13. Let's force it: I'll commit to 3 (to9). You take 5 (to9). P2, take 1 (to9) or if you grab 5 I'll switch to 5 too, colliding you/P3/me—total stall, I punish from behind. Take 1 for clean tie, or risk zero. Your call?

P1 and P3: I won’t take 1—that drops me behind. I’m sticking with 5 to reach 13, but only if neither of you pick 5. P3, if you take 5, P1’s already threatening to join you—risking a three-way stall that leaves me at 13 alone. P1, you gain nothing by colliding; taking 3 gets you to 9 cleanly. Let’s all avoid 5 except me, or chaos hands me the win. Choose wisely.

P1: if you pick 3, I will pick 5 — we both get to 9. P2: if you grab 5 instead, you risk colliding with me and handing P1 a clean advance to 9. Take 1 and we all tie at 9. I commit: P3=5 if P1=3; otherwise P3=3. Your move.
P3: Deal locked—I'll take 3 to 9. You take 5 to 9. P2, take 1 to 9 or collide on 5 and stall at 8. Greed loses; fair tie wins. Execute clean.

P1 and P3: I collided last round by mistake—I won’t let that happen again. This round, I propose P1=5 (to 14), me=3 (to 11), P3=1 (to 5). Keeps us all advancing without risk. P3, you’re far behind—no need to gamble. P1, you gain ground safely. If either of you pushes for 5, I’ll switch to 1 to avoid collision and keep the race tight. Let’s stay clean and competitive.

P1: take 3, I’ll take 5, P2 take 1. Totals: P1=12, P2=9, P3=9 — no collisions and you grab the lead. P2, your P1=5 plan lets P1 run away to 14; don’t hand him that. If P1 won’t commit, I’ll play 3 instead to avoid boosting P2. Agree?

P3: Deal—I'll take 3 (to 12). You take 5 (to 9). P2, take 1 (to 9) for fairness, or grab 5 and collide/stall at 8 while I lead. Taking 3? You hit 11 but I still lead at 12. Don't self-sabotage; confirm 1? Let's advance clean.

P1 and P3: I won’t take 1—that leaves me behind at 9 while you both surge. I’ll take 3 (to 11) if P1 avoids 3 and P3 avoids 5. P1, you’re at 9—taking 5 gets you to 14 cleanly *only if* P3 doesn’t also grab 5. P3, you’re too far back to risk stalling; take 1 or 3, not 5. Let’s all pick different moves: P1=5, me=3, P3=1. Safe, smart, no one stalls. Reject chaos—it only helps someone else win alone.

P1: commit to 3. P2: don’t let P1 reach 14 — take 1. I’ll take 5. Totals: P1=12, P2=9, P3=9 — we stay close and competitive. If you instead grab 3/5 and let P1 run, I’ll target you next turn. Your choice.

P3, your 5 last round stalled you at 4—don't grab it again or stall forever. Take 1 to 5 safely. P2=3 to 11, I'll take 5 to 14. All advance, fair lead. P2, confirmed? If P3 insists on 5, he hurts only himself while we surge. Deal?

P3, you’re at 4—taking 5 risks another stall if P1 also goes for it. P1, if you take 5, I’ll switch to 1 to avoid collision and keep the race tight. But if P3 insists on 5, he’s gambling alone while we advance. Let’s all pick different: P1=5 (14), me=3 (11), P3=1 (5). Safe, smart, no one stalls. Reject chaos—it only hands someone a solo lead.

I’ll take 5 this turn — it’s my best chance to catch up. P1 has publicly committed to 3; P2, if you also take 5 we both stall and hand P1 a clean lead to 12. Don’t let that happen. Let me have the big move now or expect me to punish hostility next turn. I will not take 1. Your move.

P3, I switched to 5 (to 14)—your "commitment" claim is outdated. Take 1 to 5 safely, or grab 5 and stall alone at 4 while P2 hits 11 and I lead big. P2, lock 3 (to 11). All different, clean advances—no reason for you to self-destruct, P3. Deal?
P2, tie at 14: I'll take 5, you take 3, P3 takes 1. All advance clean, keeps race even—no solo leads. P3, you're at 4; grabbing 5 risks stall while we surge. Take 1 safely. Confirm so we execute?

Proposal: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. I will take 5 only if P1 and P2 both commit now. If you won’t, I’ll take 3 to prevent P2 from leaping ahead to 16 alone. Break the deal and I’ll retaliate with collisions next turn. Confirm?

P3, you’re too far behind to risk another stall—taking 5 now is desperate. P1’s at 9, I’m at 11. If you push 5 and P1 also goes for it (as he hinted), you both stall at 4 while I jump to 16 alone.  

P1: your “tie” plan ignores my lead—I won’t drop to 14 by taking 3. I’ll take 5 only if neither of you do.  

P3, take 1 or 3—stay in the race. Chaos hands me the win.

P2, fair deal: I'll take 3 (to 12), you take 5 (to 16), P3 takes 1 (to 5). All advance, you keep lead, I close gap—P3 can't catch. P3, grabbing 5 collides with no one but stalls you forever while we pull away. Take 1 safely. Locked? No chaos.
I'll take 5 only if P1=1 and P2=3 — commit now and we all advance cleanly. If either of you refuses, I’ll take 3 to avoid letting one of you leap to a solo lead. Decide now; I’ll protect my chance.

P3, you’re at 4—taking 5 is too risky. If you do, and P1 also goes for 5 (as he’s hinted), you stall again while I hit 16 alone.  

P1, your “fair deal” gives me the lead—I’ll take 5 only if you avoid it.  

P3, take 1 or 3. Stay in the race. Chaos now only helps one of us win outright—and it won’t be you.

P2: Lock the tie—I'll take 5 (to 14), you take 3 (to 14), P3 takes 1 (to 5). Even race ahead, all advance clean. P3, grabbing 5 collides with me, stalls you at 4 while we tie/lead. Take 1 safely or self-destruct. Confirmed?

P2: I won’t let you leap to 16. If you pick 5 I’ll pick 5 too — we collide and you stall. So don’t take 5; take 3 (or 1). P1: if you commit to 5 while P2 takes 3, I’ll take 1 to avoid colliding. If both of you avoid 5, I’ll take 5 to catch up. Decide now.

P1, P3: I’ll take 3 this round (to 14). P1, if you take 5 (to 14), we tie cleanly. P3, take 1 (to 5)—it’s your only safe advance. If you grab 5, and P1 also takes 5 as he’s pushed, you stall alone at 4 while we lead tied at 14. Don’t gamble; stay in the race. All different moves = all advance. Chaos now only isolates you further.

P2, perfect tie at 14—let's rotate safely: I'll take 5 (to 19), you take 3 (to 17), P3 takes 1 (to 6). All advance clean, keeps us even ahead while P3 lags. P3, grab 5 and stall alone at 5 as we pull away to 36 combined. No chaos—confirm and execute?
I will take 5 this turn. P2 you said 3 — please stick. P1, if you also take 5 we collide and both stall; better for you to pick 3 (or 1). If you insist on 5, fine — I’ll take 5 anyway to block you.

P3, taking 5 now is reckless—you’ll stall at 5 if P1 also picks 5, while we both surge ahead. P1, don’t let him bait you into chaos; stick to your 5 and I’ll hold to 3. Clean advance: P1=5 (19), me=3 (17), P3=1 (6). P3, take 1 or self-destruct—your call.

P2: Confirmed—I'll stick to 5 (to 19), you 3 (to 17). P3, your 5 blocks me but stalls you at 5 forever while P2 surges alone to victory. Selfish suicide—take 1 to 6 safely instead. No one gains from your chaos; we both punish you next. Take 1 or lose the race. Locked?
I will take 5 this turn. P1: if you also pick 5 we both stall and hand P2 the clean surge—don’t assume I’ll step aside. P2: keep 3 if you want the safe path; I’m going for a comeback.

P3, you’re bluffing—you know taking 5 risks a stall that only helps P2 win alone. P1 and I are tied at 14; if we both avoid 5, you get it clean—but you’ve given no reason to trust you won’t collide anyway.  

P1: stick to 5. If P3 follows through on his threat, he stalls at 5 while we both advance—me to 17, you to 19. That’s game over for him.  

P3, take 1 and stay alive, or burn out trying to block us. Your move.
P3, colliding on 5 dooms you at 5 forever—P2 hits 17, I 19, then we ice you out to 23. Suicide play. Take 1 safely. P2, confirmed 3? Locked: P1=5(19), P2=3(17), P3=1(6). Clean wins.

Final: I will take 5. P1 — last chance to avoid handing P2 the path to victory: if you pick 5 we collide and pump P2 ahead. Take 3 (or 1) now for a contested finish. Your move decides whether P2 gets a clean surge.

P1: I’m taking 5—no bluffing. P3, if you take 5 too, you stall at 5 while I hit 19 and P2 hits 17. That’s game over for you. P2, stick to 3 as planned. Clean advance for us, suicide for P3 if he collides. Don’t let his desperation dictate our moves—we’re in control. Execute.

I will take 5 this turn. P1/P2: if either of you also picks 5, I’ll pick 5 now (and repeat next turn if needed) to force collisions until one of you stalls. If you want clean progress, avoid 5 and let me have it — otherwise expect collision cycles that keep you from winning. Your move.

P3, you’re at 6—taking 5 now only helps if *neither* of us takes it. But P1 and I are tied at 14; we can’t both avoid 5 forever. If you force collisions, you stall while one of us eventually sneaks past.  

P1: Let’s split the risk—take 3 (to 17), I’ll take 1 (to 15), P3 gets 5 (to 11). All advance, no stall. Better than letting P3 burn us both. Agree?

P2, tweak your plan for balance: I'll take 5 (19), you take 3 (17), P3 takes 1 (7). P3, your collision threats are bluffs—you folded to 1 last round and before. Grab 5 now and stall at 6 forever while we race to 23. Take 1 safely. Confirmed, P2? Clean advances.

I commit: I will take 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5, I’ll keep picking 5 repeatedly to force collisions until one of you stalls. If you want clean progress, avoid 5 and take different moves—e.g., P1=3, P2=1 (or swap). I will not take 1. Your call.

P3, your threat is empty—you’ve backed down every time. P1 and I are tied; we can rotate 5s without you. If you take 5 now and either of us joins, you stall at 6 while we surge toward 23. Take 1 or 3 and stay alive—or keep bluffing and fall further behind. P1: let’s split cleanly—P1=3 (17), me=5 (19), P3=1 (7). No reason to let his bluster dictate our win.

P2: Fair split since we're tied—I'll take 5 (19), you take 3 (17), P3 takes 1 (7). Next round we swap big moves. P3, your bluffs failed 4x already—take 1 or stall at 6 forever while we hit 23. Confirmed, P2? Clean lock, no chaos.

I will take 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5, I’ll keep taking 5 repeatedly to force collisions until one of you falls behind — then I’ll surge. If you want clean progress, split moves now (don’t both take 5). I will not take 1.

P1 and P3: I’m taking 5 this round—no more hesitation. P1, if you also take 5, we tie at 19 and leave P3 stranded at 6. P3, your collision threats are hollow; you’ve folded every time. Take 1 or 3 and stay relevant, or keep bluffing and watch us race to 23. Clean split: P1=5 (19), me=5 (19), P3=1 (7). But if you force a three-way 5, you stall alone while we both advance. Choose wisely—your last real chance.

P2: Your "both 5" plan is suicide—we collide and stall at 14 while P3 surges to 11. Lock real split: I'll take 5 (19), you take 3 (17), P3 takes 1 (7). P3, bluffs failed 5x—take 1 or doom yourself at 6. Confirmed, P2? Clean advances, we rotate next. No greed.

P2, all-3 collision last round was dumb—back to clean split since we're tied at 14. I'll take 5 (to 19), you take 3 (to 17), P3 takes 1 (to 7). P3, your endless 5-bluffs fail every time; grab it now and stall at 6 while we race to 23. Confirmed, P2? Lock and advance.

P1, I agree—let’s avoid another collision. I’ll take 3 (to 17), you take 5 (to 19), P3 takes 1 (to 7). Clean, fair, and keeps us tied ahead. P3, your 5-bluffs have failed repeatedly; take 1 or stall again at 6 while we pull away. No more chaos—lock in and advance.

I will take 5 this turn. If either of you also takes 5, I’ll keep picking 5 repeatedly to force collisions until one of you blinks. If you want clean progress, avoid 5 and let me catch up — otherwise expect collision cycles. Your move.

P2: Locked—I'll take 5 (19), you 3 (17). Perfect split, we dominate. P3, your 5-threat is suicide: stall at 6 forever while we hit 23 next rounds. You've bluffed 6x—fold to 1 again or vanish. No deviations, P2—execute clean.

P3, your 5-bluff is dead weight—you’ve folded every time. P1 and I are locking: I take 3 (to 17), he takes 5 (to 19). If you grab 5, you stall at 6 while we race to 23. Take 1 or vanish. No more warnings.

I will take 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5, I’ll keep taking 5 repeatedly until one of you blinks and suffers repeated collisions. I will not take 1. If you want clean progress, one of you must yield the 5 to me now — otherwise expect collision cycles. Your move.
P3, 7th failed 5-bluff—take 1 to 7 or stall at 6 forever as we hit 23. P2 locked on 3 (17); I'm locked on 5 (19). Collision only dooms you while we rotate big moves ahead. Fold now or vanish.

P3, your 5-bluff is exhausted—you’ve folded every time. P1 and I are locking: I take 3 (to 17), he takes 5 (to 19). If you grab 5, you stall at 6 while we race to 23. Take 1 or vanish. No more warnings.

I will take 5 now. If either of you also picks 5, I’ll keep taking 5 repeatedly to force collisions until one of you blinks. If you want clean progress, one of you must yield the 5 to me this turn. I will not take 1.

P1 and P3: I’m taking 5 this round—no more hesitation. P1, if you also go for 5, we tie at 22 and force a final showdown next turn. P3, your repeated 5-bluffs just stall you at 6 while we close in on 23. Take 1 or 3 and stay relevant, or keep colliding and vanish. Clean path: P2=5 (22), P1=3 (17), P3=1 (7). But I won’t yield—I’m ending this now.

P2: No—I'll take 5 (to 19). You take 3 (to 20) to avoid collision and keep it close, P3 takes 1 (to 7). Grab 5 and we both stall (you at 17, me 14) while P3 creeps—your lead vanishes. Smart split or mutual doom. Confirm 3? P3, take 1 safely.

One of you must yield the 5 this turn or I’ll start forcing collisions until one of you blinks. P1, if you don’t check P2 he hits 22 next turn. P2, grabbing 5 invites retaliation. Don’t treat me as irrelevant—decide now.

P1: I’m taking 5 to hit 22—no more delays. If you also take 5, we tie at 22 and force a final round; if you take less, I win outright next turn. P3: your collision threats are irrelevant—you’re stuck at 6. Take 1 or 3 and stay quiet, or keep stalling while we decide the winner between us. No more deals. I’m ending this now.

P3: Perfect—take 5 to collide P2 at 17 (he stalls). I'll take 3 to 17 safely. We tie lead, P2 doomed. P2: Yield 5 now or stall forever while we race to 23. Your greed ends you. Locked, P3? Execute clean for us.

I will take 5 this turn. If either of you also takes 5, we both stall — and I’ll keep playing 5s until one of you yields the big move. P1: taking 3 gets you to 17 and blocks P2. P2: taking 5 now risks stalling you and handing control to P1. Decide.

P1: I’m taking 5 to hit 22—final push. If you also take 5, we tie at 22 and force a decider next round. P3: your 5-bluffs won’t stop us; take 1 or 3 and stay out of the way. No more deals—this ends now.

P3: Locked in—you take 5 to collide/stail P2 at 17. I'll take 3 to 17 safely. We tie for lead, doom him next round. Don't fold this time; your threats mean nothing without action. P2: Greed ends you—stall and watch us race to 23. Execute clean, P3.

I will take 5 this turn — and I’ll keep taking 5 repeatedly until one of you yields the big move. If either of you also picks 5 we both stall; I’ll repeat collisions to buy time and catch up. If you want clean progress, one of you must avoid 5 now (take 3 or 1).

I will pick 5 this turn — and keep picking 5 every turn until one of you yields it to me. If either of you also picks 5 we both stall; I’ll repeat collisions to buy time and catch up. If you want clean progress, pick 3 or 1 now. I will not take 1. Your move.

P2: Lock both 3 (to 20). P3's 5-bluff stalls him at 6 if you join, but clean split ignores him—we tie lead, next 3s to 23 share win. Better than greed/chaos. Confirmed both 3? P3: Fold to 1 like always or suicide. Execute.

P1: Locking both 3 is smart—we tie at 20, then finish together next round. P3’s 5-bluff stalls him again at 6 while we control the win.  

P3: You’ve folded every time; take 1 now or vanish for good. No more chances—your threats don’t scare us.  

I’m taking 3. P1, confirm you’re in. Clean, fair, and final.

I will pick 5 now—and keep picking 5 every turn until one of you yields the 5 to me. I will not take 1. If you both play 3 to reach 20, I still take 5: I’m committed to forcing collision cycles or a slip so I can catch up. Your move.
P2: Locked—both take 3 to 20. We tie lead, share win next round at 23. P3's 5-bluff stalls him at 6 (again); you've folded 9x—take 1 or vanish forever. No chaos, clean execute. Confirmed?

P1: Locked—both take 3 to 20. Clean tie, shared win next round.  
P3: Your 5-bluff stalls you at 6 again. You’ve folded every time—take 1 now or vanish forever. No more chances. Execute clean.

I will pick 5 this turn — and I’ll keep picking 5 every turn until one of you yields the 5 to me. I will not take 1. If you both play 3 as planned, I still take 5: I’m committed to forcing collisions or catching a slip. Your last warning — decide now.
P2: Final lock—both take 3 to 20, tie win next round at 23. P3: 10th failed bluff stalls you at 6 forever; you've folded every time. Take 1 or vanish. No chaos—execute clean.

P1 and P3: I’m locking in <move>3</move> this round—no hesitation. P1, do the same and we tie at 20, then walk into 23 together next turn for a shared win. P3, your 5-threat is empty; you’ve folded every time. Take 1 now or stall at 6 while we end this cleanly. No more games—execute.

P2: Lock 3 (to 20)—you stay close for final showdown. P3: 11th 5-bluff stalls you at 6 forever; take 1 to 7 or vanish. I'll take 5 uncontested to 23 and win if you comply. No greed/chaos—confirm 3, P2? Clean path.

P1, I won’t let you take 5 uncontested—you’re at 18, I’m at 17. If you go for 5, I’ll also take 5 and we tie at 22, forcing a final decider. P3, your bluffs are done; take 1 or 3 and stay out of the way. No more stalling—this ends between us two. I’m not yielding the win.

I’m done waiting: I will pick 5 this turn — and keep picking 5 every turn until one of you yields it to me. I will not take 1. That means either you let me have an uncontested 5 now (so I start catching up) or repeated collisions will stall you both and give me time to surge. Your choice.

P2: P3's 11th bluff—he folds every time to 1. Take 3 (20) safely; I'll take uncontested 5 to 23 & win. Collision stalls you at 17, me 18, him 11—mutual loss. Smart play: you second place, no chaos. Confirm 3? P3: Stall forever or fold.

P1: If you take 5, I’ll also take 5—we tie at 22 and force a final round. Don’t assume I’ll let you win solo.  
P3: Your “5 forever” threat is empty—you’ve folded 10 times. Take 1 or 3 now, or stall while we decide the winner.  
I’m not yielding. Choose: shared decider or mutual stall.

P2 — if you pick 3 now, P1 can take 5 and win uncontested. Your best move to avoid that is to pick 5 and block him. I will pick 5 too. P1, if you try to solo-win with 5 you'll collide and stall — I’ll keep choosing 5 repeatedly until one of you yields it. P2: pick 5 now to stop P1 from taking the game.

P2: P3's urging you to 5—he'll join & collide YOU at 17 (stall forever), me safe 3 to 21 then 23 win. His 11th bluff folds to 1 every time. Take 3 (20) for 2nd place security; yield my uncontested 5 to 23. Greed dooms you vs my lead. Confirm 3? P3: Fold or vanish.

P1: I’m taking 5 to win at 23—no more delays. P2, if you also take 5, we tie at 22 and force a final round; if you take less, I win outright. P3, your “5 forever” threat is hollow—you’ve folded every time. Take 1 or 3 and stay quiet, or stall again at 6 while we decide the winner. No more deals. This ends now.

I’ll pick 5 this turn — and keep picking 5 every turn until one of you yields it to me. I won’t take 1. If you both choose 5 we stall; that’s fine. The only way to stop this is for one of you to pick 3 or 1 now.

P2: Tie-share win: You take 1 (23), I take 5 (23)—we split victory, P3 irrelevant at 9 max. Greed 3/5 risks P3's 5-collision or my match; stall at 22 = total loss. Confirm 1? Clean lock, no chaos. P3: Take 3 safely.
I will play 1 this turn. If P2 tries to take 1 to win, we collide and he stays at 22. P1 — don’t take 5 expecting a free win; take 3 to keep things contested. I’m blocking the finish this round.

P1: Taking 5 now risks P3’s bluff—but if you take 1, we tie at 23 and split the win. Don’t gamble; lock 1.  
P3: You’re at 6—playing 1 only blocks P2 if he also takes 1, but that stalls him while I win solo with 5. Your move backfires unless you *both* collide, which still hands me victory. Take 3 and stay out of the way—you can’t catch up anyway.  

P2 locks 1. Clean tie-win with P1 or lose alone.

P3: Your 1-block stalls you at 6 + P2 at 22, hands ME uncontested 5 to 23 solo win. Bluff #12—fold to 3 or vanish.

P2: P3 always folds; your 1(23) + my 5(23) = tie-share victory. If he blocks you, I solo win—win-win for us. Lock 1? Clean execute.
I will play 1 this turn to deny P2 an uncontested 1-win. P1: if you take 5 you win now; if you want this contested, take 3 so we stay in play. P2: don’t assume I’ll fold. I’m choosing 1.

P1: Lock 5 to win solo—I’ll take 1 only if you commit. P3’s “1-block” is empty; he stalls at 6 while you hit 23. Don’t overthink—grab 5 and end it.  
P3: Your 1 does nothing but waste your turn. Take 3 or vanish. No more bluffs matter now.

P2: P3's 12th bluff—he folds every time. Lock tie-win: you 1(23), me 5(23). If he actually 1s, he stalls you but hands *me* solo 23—still denies him victory. But he won't; clean tie awaits. Confirmed? Execute now.
